entry.title: The Last Day of School
entry.content:
The end of a school year is always an array of emotion.  Everyone has been anticipating and counting down the last few weeks, and then the last few days of school.  However, when the end actually arrives, the excitement of the long anticipated summer vacation becomes blended with sadness and separation anxiety.  For me, this year is a particularly mixed bag of emotions as I am excited to return to my home in Florida, but realize how much of myself I've poured into the students, families and staff that I've worked with this year as a Teacher on Special Assignment.  This year's assignment has been special indeed.

My family decided to seize the opportunity to move back into our home in Sunrise, FL when it became available in January.  The home that we lived in prior to moving to California was the placed on the market in December.  Just by chance, while surfing the Internet over the holiday break, I came across the listing. Once we saw the listing, my wife, our son and I decided that we had to jump on the opportunity to purchase our home. We were so excited, but I couldn't leave my "special assignment" mid year.  I had too much invested in the children and the program.  Therefore, my wife, Joi, left on January 30th to return to our home. Our 22-year-old daughter, who was still living in Sunrise, moved back into our house with Joi.  Josh and I stayed in California to finish the school year.  So, today is a day of celebration that we made it through a very long period of our family being divided between coasts.  Joi and I knew that it was the best decision for me to stay and finish out the school year.  She really gets the balance of optimal closeness and optimal distance involved in the connections I develop in any given school year.

Parents have a life-long invested relationship advocating for their child.  This is especially true when parenting a child with special needs.  Parents develop a level of optimal closeness with their child, and they are the experts on their child.  This is why parents play such an important role on the IEP team.  Developing  a trusting relationship with open lines of communication is one of the key steps in serving as a child's teacher.  As a teacher, I am invested in each student 100%.  As a child's teacher, I think of that child as "my kid" just as a parent does. My energy is focused on getting to know how the child learns, what makes they happy, and what calms them when they are upset.  For children on the spectrum, this can be quite an investigation.  Parents provide great insight.  However, the trusting relationship of optimal closeness as  teacher is a bond that develops between the teacher and the child, and a bond that develops between the parent and the teacher.  As the school year comes to a close, students transition on to the next level of schooling, this relationship becomes one of optimal distance.

When working with preschoolers, one of my favorite age-groups, one thing that often makes me sad is thinking that the children are at an age where they won't remember me as they continue on their journey in life.  However, optimal distance develops from the investment I've made as that child's teacher. Each child I teach leaves an imprint my heart that will last forever.  I enjoy keeping in touch and hearing updates of how "my children" are progressing year after year.  Having this blog will provide an avenue for staying in touch and staying connected.

This year, I have also worked with a tremendous staff.  However, we have navigated a sea of changes which has been a challenge.  Another reason why leaving mid-year was not an option.  As a new team of TOSA's and a new program coordinator for Autism services, we faced a huge learning curve as we started the year.  Through the year, I have found that our common denominator is wanting the best for children.  The process of defining "the best" and implementing "the best" has been the heart of the challenge, and will continue to evolve.  I look forward to hearing from the team as the evolution of the program continues.  The last day of school brings the emotion of fulfillment as I feel that I've done my part to contribute.  However, also feeling that I'm leaving in the midst of a work in progress.  Autism services will continue to grow and provide children with the best foundation for learning, and the level of support needed as the children transition  into, and through, elementary school.

So, with my mixed bag of emotions, I head off now to enjoy, celebrate and say "so long" to an incredible group of professionals, parents and students.  Happy last day of school, and have a great summer vacation!

entry.title: My journey to becoming The Autism Spectrum Teacher
entry.content:
My first teaching job was as an assistant professor teaching neurology in chiropractic colleges.  For ten years, I taught neuroanatomy, neurophysiology and neurology.  I was fascinated with learning how the human nervous system forms and develops, and how the brain works.  At the same time, my passion for education grew.  During my "decade of neurology" my other passion was being the mother of three young children.

As my youngest son entered kindergarten, it became apparent that he was having difficulty  speaking and learning.  The process of getting him evaluated and eligible for special education services was a new learning curve.  One which shifted my career in education in a way that merged my interest in neurology with my passion for learning and young children.  With a Masters degree in Education, and a Doctor of Chiropractic Degree, I said "good-bye" to my neurology teaching career in order to embrace my new career as a special education teacher.

During the 2005-2006 school year, I was hired as the first special education teacher for the inagural year of Easter Seals Charter School in Daytona Beach, FL, teaching in a full inclusion preschool program. The class consisted of 50% of students with special needs, and 50% typical developing 3 to 5 year-old preschoolers.  The majority of students with special needs were students on the autism spectrum. I earned a temporary teaching credential by taking the Flordia teacher credenitaling exams.  Additionally, through networking with other preschool special education teachers from Volusia County School District, I was accepted into a grant-funded 18 credit graduate program through the University of Central Flordia for an endorsement program for PreKindergarten disabilities, an endorsement for the FL Exceptional Student Education  (ESE) teacher certification.  

Additionally, as I took courses in early childhood education at Daytona Beach College, the director of the  program learned of my Masters in Education and my job teaching at Easter Seals, and offered me an adjunct position teaching in the Early Childhood Education program.  Among the courses I taught during my year and a half tenure as an adjunct professor was "Teaching the Exceptional Learner".

For the 2006-07 school year, I was recruited to teach a preschool special education class within the school district of Volusia county.  I taught a varied exceptionalities class with preschool students with mild to moderate disabilities, including students on the Autism Spectrum at Indian River Elementary School in Edgewater, FL.  During this year, as I was completing the prekindergarten disabilities endoresment, a second endorsement program for autism became available through Florida State University. I completed the autism endorsement program during this year.  I also continued teaching in the evenings and summers for Daytona Beach College.  My temporary teaching certificate was converted to a professionl educator certification after completing two years of teaching, and taking some additional coursework through the teacher induction program. 

After teaching Extended School Year at Indian River Elementary, we relocated to south Florida.  At the teacher job faire for the School Board of Broward County, I was offered a teaching position at Sawgrass Elementary School for a self-contained class for students with autism in grades 3rd through 5th.  I was excited about the challenge of teaching older students, and learned so much about adapting and differentiating curriculum to meet a wide variety of indivdual needs.  However, I learned even more about autism this year

While visiting my family in California in August 2008, my family discussed a possible relocation to California to assist my aging mother and grandmother.  In preparation for a possible move the following summer, I submitted an application with San Lorenzo Unified School District a day before we were scheduled to return to Florida.  I was called for an interview immediately after dropping off my application.  The director of special education offered my a position teaching in a preschool autism class that the district was opening for the 2008-2009 school year. 

I accepted the position, and taught the preschool autism class for San Lorenzo Unified School District during the 2008-2009 school year.  Just after returning to California, and right before school began,  I received a call from Capella University congratulating me on being the recepient of a $50,000 scholarship to pursue a Ph.D. in Special Education Leadership.  I opened my new classroom on August 20, 2008 and started classes as a full-time graduate student on October 5, 2008.  My Florida teaching certification was accepted through receprocity for a preliminary Moderate to Severe Special Education teaching credential and an Early Childhood Specialist teaching credential in California.  In order to clear my California teaching credential, I was requrired to earn the CLAD (English as a Second Language) credential before 2013.

For the 2009-2010 school year, I was offered a position as a Teacher on Special Assignment (TOSA) for autism services for Mountain View Whisman School District.  During this year, I have also completed all courses for the PhD program, a 320 hour internship with the Director of Special Education, and my comprehensive examinations.  I am now looking forward to beginning my dissertation this summer. Another accomplishment completed this school year was earning my CLAD certification to clear my California teaching credential. I completed the CLAD program online through Stanford University.  In a future blog, I'll explain how the CLAD program and my dissertation are connected.

As fate would have it, my mother and grandmother are doing better.  Therefore, my family and I have decided to return to our home in Florida.  As the 2009-2010 school year comes to an end this week, I will be saying "good-bye" to teaching in Calfornia, and look forward to a new opportunity to serve student with Autism again in Broward County.  My noamdic journey over the past five years has been an excellent opportunity to learn and work with a vast number of professionals, families and students who are on the Autism Spectrum.  However, I am now ready to settle down in one location and teach in one place for awhile. 

Teaching students with autism is intuitive for me. People often remark of the patience I must have to work with this population.  However, for me, it is a perfect fit.  I adore working with the students, because from them, I learn so much.  I am fascinated by each one, and motivated to find the best way to teach and connect with them.  I also enjoy working closely with each family, as I firmly believe that it takes a village to educate a student with autism. 

I look forward to sharing more of my experiences as The Autism Spectrum Teacher through this blog.
